If you watch the entire video by Mark Rober, you will realize that the change in pitch is not a result of the change in the speed of sound in the different mediums.   In order to change the frequency you must change the vibration of the source.   When you hear a sound traveling through water or through air the pitch does not change, the medium does not affect the frequency, only the speed and wavelength.  The heavier particles of the gasses cause the vocal cords to have less acceleration and thus lower frequency. OOpps. breathing helium doesn't change the frequency but changes the formant. The frequency is determined by the tightness of the vocal cords and the force of the lungs, and that remains almost the same. What changes is the speed of the sound bouncing around the  mouth and nasal cavity which form the spectral filters, like the sound of which vowel we hear. The frequency of the filters do go up in pitch meaning that the harmonic envelope rises in pitch but the fundamental frequency it self doesn"t change. So it's like your mouth and nose and in fact your whole head has shrunk but the vocal cords haven't. Try a pitch detector on your vocal range with helium and without and you'll find it is the same.

At last, someone said light isn't constant! Interestingly, though, Planck's constant isn't constant, but they're inversely proportional, and their product is constant. Therefore, combining that with the knowledge of Planck pairs vs uncertainty, this possibility presents itself: the universe isn't expanding, but instead light used to travel at different speeds, depending on Planck's constant, and that is actually what causes redshift. If it's a cycle, as with most of the universe, this means that people centuries from now, or even decades, might start to see galaxies blueshifting! (The idea of c and h being changeable, but their product being constant, also means the universe is not expanding, so even if it's true, it may be years before scientists are uncomfortable enough with what light's doing to consider it, and it also handles both dark energy and dark matter, making them unnecessary theories.)

coming from an sound engineering background: this is a very bad way to teach waves. what's the squiggly line for? oh it's a plot of the amplitude of the wave over time. saying "that squiggly line is a wave" is kind of an empty statement. the time is not equal to the period although it's calculated in units of time, but rather the period is the time that it takes for the wave to come back to a rest point i.e. a full cycle so it should be "period = time/cycle" and "period = 1/frequency"

Excellent lesson but was there a a glitch a https://youtu.be/Y1LbQBgvISs?t=787 suggesting the big dishes of radio telescopes are due to large wavelengths? Most radio astronomy done with dish antennas is in the GHz range corresponding to centimetric or smaller wavelengths. The big dish is capture lots of super weak waves ie it provides gain by reflecting them many directions onto the actual antenna usually at the end of the stalk in the middle, but sometimes in so-called Cassegrain antennas the stalk just carries another small reflector which concentrates the signals into the mouth of a waveguide at the dish centre. This is when you're operating at frequencies where cables are increasingly lossy and it's better to use interconnection methods more akin to plumbing preserve the precious signals.

I feel like the statement that energy goes up with frequency is basically wrong. Like, yes, it's true for light photons, but that's a quantum phenomenon. In the case of acoustic waves, voltage waves, waves in a string etc, the energy depends only on amplitude and not on frequency. And in water waves, energy is, if anything, inversely proportional to frequency.

From a seismology approach, longitudinal (P waves) and transverse (S waves) waves  are considered body waves in that they both travel through a medium.  It should be noted that transverse waves can only travel though solid materials because fluids by definition do not have a shear modulus.   Surface waves are those that travel along the flexible boundary between two media.  Surface waves on the ocean surface are Rayleigh waves, which also travel on land when produced by earthquakes and cause the major damage.

Fun fact: Ham radio operators use a shorthand method for determining broadcast bands: Take the frequency you are using, for instance the 93.5x10^6Hz, but represent that in MhZ. Divide 300 by that number, such that 300/93.5 =~ 3, and that is the general broadcast band you are in: the 3m band. It is a very general equation, but it comes in handy for determining what band you are in with simple in-the-head arithmetic. Where is the frequency range for the 10m band? Oh, around 30MHz (Ham radio operators use around the 28MHz range, but this is really close)

I've always disliked the idea of an expanding universe used to explain away the redshift of distant galaxies.  What is the cause of the expansion? Well, they say it must be expanding because light is redshifted but they always leave it at that and go on to the next chapter in book of cosmetology. Yeah, I was taught the big bang explosion started it off but why 20 years later in our investigation of the universe has it had to speed up even more to explain the extra redshifts as we peer deeper and deeper into the past.  Why can't redshift be explained by something simpler like the entropy of time in the spacetime equation or light passing through clouds of gas?  No, we have to have an elaborate system of expansion, reminds me of the crystal spheres that used to house the planets and stars prior to the invention of the solar system.

The Science Asylum did a video a while ago about the speed of light. In that video he discussed the theory that the individual photons don't actually slow down in matter. About that bumper sticker: using non-relativistic doppler, you get a required speed of around 0.75c. Obviously that's a sign that you shouldn't trust the non-relativistic doppler formula to give the right answer in this case, and the actual answer is, I'm told around 0.5c instead. Which, yes, would be traveling too fast, but wouldn't be a problem for long since in a few seconds they'd be past the moon's orbit, leaving a trail of devastation back on Earth (or they'd have disintegrated due to trying to pass through solid air molecules)
